©1995-2007 Gazetteer for Scotland
The name Wick derives from the norse "vik" meaning bay and emphasises the Viking past of the area. Its proximity to Europe led to its elevation to royal burgh status (1589)
column3: and its exclusive right to trade abroad. However
column4:
it did not really develop until 1803 when Thomas Telford began his work on the harbour and on a new town to the south of Wick. This new development was named Pulteneytown and existed as a separate council until 1902 when it was incorporated into the royal burgh.

A market town for the local area
column5: Wick was also an important herring fishing port. With the decline in herring
column6: employment has been established in light industries and with the foundation of the Caithness Glass Factory in 1961 by Robin Sinclair
column7:
Lord Thurso. The company went into receivership in 2003 and the Wick factory closed.

Wick is well served by road and rail links
column9: situated 2 miles (3 km) north of the town
column10:
with flights to all of Scotland's major cities.

Places of interest include the Wick Heritage Centre
column11: with its blacksmith's shop and curing yard with kipper kiln and cooperage
column12: the ruins of Castle Oliphant which date back to the 14th Century
column13: the remnants of Bucholly Castle which dates back to the Viking invaders
column14: and the Wick Gala Week which occurs in the last week of July. Tourist will also find a golf course
